subNodes.conversationText: I would like to look at your arms and armor.
Well, I'm the town smith and the town leader.  My great-uncle was Saern Bairnson.  We Bairnsons were the ones who renovated Swordskeep and started building on the crag.
He died forty years ago, when I was just an apprentice smith.  A sad day for all of Drawn Swords.  I'm not ashamed to admit that no leader is likely ever to compare with him, including me.
What can you tell me about Drawn Swords?
Well, the town you see now has stood here for a little over a century.  This keep has been around for about twice as long, and belonged to an ill-tempered robber knight named Ludos.
No one can mention Drawn Swords without talking about the Sword and Dragon Inn.  Danmar's management of the place has made Drawn Swords a destination for travelers in the Backlands.
[Tell Hamfast about the Zhentarim military portfolio, the apparent fall of Darkhold, and your encounters in Northdark Wood.]

My.  This is serious.  Even though their plans seem to have nothing to do with our town, it makes me uneasy.  Even if we are not a target, we could end up being casualties of whatever trouble they're gonna cause.  And trouble there will be, mark my words.
We certainly got more than we bargained for, <FirstName>.
Manfred's murderers have been dealt with--to a degree.  Are you satisfied, Vroman?
I can't quite place it, but I feel as if something is still wrong. We have killed many Zhentarim, but I do not feel as if I am any closer to figuring out--why. Why did it have to be Manfred?

Ah, Vroman.  You are grieving.  It is not always up to those of us who continue to live to question why those who have passed have passed.  There is never any sure answer.  But I respect your feelings.

I understand what you're feeling, but you did what you needed to.  You can't take on all of the Zhentarim, dispersed or no.  Manfred's death was senseless and cruel, but nothing we can discover will change that.
Aye, these are big doings, bigger than any of us.  Still, I can't help but wonder if we oughtn't do something.
I agree--both for Vroman's sake, and for the sake of all--we need to investigate the Zhentarim presence further.
Well, good.  I intend to speak to Danmar--the innkeeper, you know--about this.  Since you want to help, and because you're the ones with the news, maybe you ought to join in.
Come to my house--right next to the inn--when you are ready.  My wife, Sarah, has a pheasant soup that will fill your bellies, and some fresh squash from the lowlands.
And--ah.  Before I forget, here's some gold for your work.  It's not much, but it's about all we can afford.
The reward is not necessary, Hamfast.  I thank you for the gesture, though.
Well, suit yourselves!  You are very welcome, and I am grateful--we are not a very rich settlement.
As I said, we will meet at my house when you are ready.  Until then, farewell.
Well, suit yourselves!  You are very welcome, and I am grateful--we are not a very rich settlement.
I thank you, Hamfast. [Take a purse of two hundred gold pieces from the smith.]
I do not see any other option, frankly.
Vroman and I are willing to help.  Ianth and Gossam--what are your opinions?
I am still committed to protecting Drawn Swords; besides, you know that I have a personal interest in the Zhentarim presence here as well.
I left Corm Orp for adventure, and adventure I have found.  Also, Corm Orp is near Darkhold--so I certainly have some personal interest in the matter.
Vroman and I are willing to help.  What is your opinion, Ianth?
I am still committed to protecting Drawn Swords; besides, you know that I have a personal interest in the Zhentarim presence here as well.
Yes, but I do not regret it.  I feel as if the adventure has only just begun.
Perhaps so.  I, for one, would not be against pursuing this further.
I need nothing at the moment.  Farewell.
[Sleight of Hand] [Hamfast is not particularly attentive. You might be able to secure a small bag of what look like semiprecious stones from a nearby workbench.] Oh, I need nothing at the moment...
[Success] [You gingerly pick up the bag of stones and pocket it swiftly. Hamfast remains none the wiser.]

[Failure] Now, wait a minute!  I know that you are an adventurer, <FirstName>, but I can't have you traipsing out of here with those little jewels.  You'll have to find another blacksmith's shop to make an adventure out of.
Put them back where you found them, please.

[Hamfast seems merrier than usual.] Ah, my favorite adventurers have returned! I am sure you have news for me. I also have some news for you! But first tell me what you discovered at the encampment. Did you defeat General Clydus?
No.  The Banites were killed by a group of Cyricists who attacked us when we approached the camp.
Then two bands of Zhentarim have been beaten. It's a damn shame the camp was ransacked before you got there. You saw no Banites, then?
Well, yes...[Tell Hamfast about your encounter with the mercenaries led by Marcellus.]
It is true. One of the mercenaries is known to me. He used to work for my father. I...I think that he is a mercenary before he is a Banite, though.
Hm.  It's hard to say with such folk, Miss Ianth.  You didn't question him?
I know him well enough to know that questions would have been useless.
Well, at least we know now that our guesses were right, and that the Bane and Cyric worshippers are at war.
Yes. I have one additional thing to report: the leader of the Cyricists said something about wanting Vroman captured. We have no idea why. Vroman claims to be ignorant as well.
Something else has been troubling us, and especially Vroman.  It seems that the Cyric-worshippers wanted to capture him for some reason.
Aren't you going to tell him about that Cyric-worshipper's little speech to me, <FirstName>?  Apparently, they want me captured.
Something about "penetrating a ruse."  I have no idea what the man was talking about, I assure you.  By the grace of the Lady of Luck, I've never even met a Cyricist!  Or...not until I met that one.
Then they know more than we thought!  Damn, Danmar won't be pleased.
What are you talking about?  What do you know that we don't?!
As I said, I've got some news for you--[Hamfast glances over at the chapel staircase.]
[You turn and see a slim, travel-weary gentleman who you did not notice when you came in. His features look familiar--]
No. [Keep the news of your encounter with the mercenaries led by Marcellus secret.]
[Ianth give you a subtle nod of gratitude.]
General Clydus was dead before we got there, as were all of his men.  Cyricists killed them and then tried to kill us.
Not quite, though I'm sure we could have. We took on a bunch of Cyric-worshippers instead.

You know, I still haven't compensated the lot of you for checking out that second camp.  I was thinking I might do something special for you this time around, if you'd like--especially seeing as you continue to help Drawn Swords.
What did you have in mind?

Here's the thing.  I've had a good amount of adamant laying about for a few years--bought if off a dwarf on his way through from the Great Rift.  I always wanted to test my skill on it, but never knew what to make of it.
Well, Hamfast, I hope you think of something.  I'm not much of a smith, if that's what you're getting at.
By Moradin, I can't imagine how you let such stuff lie about for so long.  You're no dwarf, that's for sure!
So you would like to forge something for me, I take it?

What I'm thinking is this.  You tell me what kind of weapon you'd like, and I'll forge an adamantine version of it for you.  How's that?  If that doesn't suit you, the town could cough up five hundred gold pieces.
I would be honored if you could make a weapon for me.
There you are.  I hope you didn't mind the wait.  Use it well!
Er...Sorry.  I'm not exactly sure how to go about making that one.
Very well.  I don't know what I'll do with all that adamant, but I'm sure I'll think of something one of these days.
As long as the compensation seems fair, I'll consider it.
Ah, <FirstName>, I'd hoped you knew me well enough by now to know I wouldn't bamboozle you.
Have you had any success discovering what happened to Brother Anselm?
Nay, we're still looking into the matter.

You know, I still haven't compensated the lot of you for checking out that second camp.  I was thinking I might do something special for you this time around, if you'd like--especially seeing as you continue to help Drawn Swords.
What did you have in mind?

Here's the thing.  I've had a good amount of adamant laying about for a few years--bought if off a dwarf on his way through from the Great Rift.  I always wanted to test my skill on it, but never knew what to make of it.
Well, Hamfast, I hope you think of something.  I'm not much of a smith, if that's what you're getting at.
By Moradin, I can't imagine how you let such stuff lie about for so long.  You're no dwarf, that's for sure!
So you would like to forge something for me, I take it?

What I'm thinking is this.  You tell me what kind of weapon you'd like, and I'll forge an adamantine version of it for you.  How's that?  If that doesn't suit you, the town could cough up five hundred gold pieces.
I would be honored if you could make a weapon for me.
There you are.  I hope you didn't mind the wait.  Use it well!
Er...Sorry.  I'm not exactly sure how to go about making that one.
Very well.  I don't know what I'll do with all that adamant, but I'm sure I'll think of something one of these days.
As long as the compensation seems fair, I'll consider it.
Ah, <FirstName>, I'd hoped you knew me well enough by now to know I wouldn't bamboozle you.
Yes, Hamfast. Brother Anselm is dead. It appears that he was murdered...[Tell Hamfast about the note and the grisly scene.]
Murdered!  Well, this is indeed a surprise.  And the place was still locked, the window unbroken, and no one in town the wiser.  Whoever did it must have had a key.
It must have been that blasted acolyte, the Cyricist!
Both of those acolytes had keys to Anselm's place.  Well, I'd say you should head off and find out what this "BMT" wants, but I'll wager that whoever it is isn't going to want to chat kindly.
I intend to head off as soon as possible.  In the mean time, you should secure yourself and Sarah as well as possible.
[Trying his best not to appear shaken.] Oh, don't worry about me. I know how to defend myself better than Anselm did. Poor Anselm! Take care of yourselves.
I will investigate.  But first--Are you all right, Hamfast?
The bastard who did this will fall by my hand.
[Trying his best not to look shaken.] I hope so, I hope so!
Of course.  We'll be on our way.
Not yet.  We have other business to discuss with you.
What news from Northdark Wood?!  Has the murderer been dealt with?
Yes, though we fear the murder was not an isolated incident...[Tell Hamfast about your encounter.]
I can't say that I'm happy you showed mercy to the ones who killed Anselm, but it's good that the Cyricists they worked for are killed.
It may have been for my benefit, Anselm, that <FirstName> allowed Marcellus and his cohort to escape.  Marcellus..served my father.
To think that they murdered poor Anselm just so that they could ambush the lot of you!  Well, you've done your best for the town once again, <FirstName> and company, and I've another reward for you.
You know that a reward is hardly necessary at this point, Hamfast.  Keep your money.
You truly are a devoted <class> of <Deity>, <FirstName>.  I thank you--the winter will come soon, and Drawn Swords will need all the money it can keep.
I thank you--the winter will come soon, and Drawn Swords will need all the money it can keep.
[Sighing, and looking slightly abashed.] Well, Mistress Ianth--and --I don't want this to sound wrong, but--
Well, it's just that--I think your being here might bring further trouble to the town, and as a Bairnson, I can't let that happen.  I'll do all I can for you--
Do not trouble yourself, Hamfast. It has been almost a year exactly. I am sad to leave your service, but it is necessary--for the town, for us, and for me.
I suppose I should say goodbye to Uncle Asterchord before I go.  This is a lovely spot; I shall cherish the memory of your town for a long time, Master Bairnson.
I am sad to leave this place myself. Circumstance has given it a peculiar poignance for me, too. [As Vroman speaks, Hamfast's eyes widen at something behind you.]
[You turn around to see three knights bearing the arms of the Ruby Rose. Their leader speaks--] Sister Ianth!
By the Firehair, Brother Maerdred!  What brings you here at this hour?
The Order was worried.  Your pilgrimage to the Flame Stone had taken many months longer than expected.  We...also have reason to believe that the Flame Stone itself might be in danger.
Whatever do you mean, Maerdred?  The Stag Warriors guard the place, and no evil can come near it.
I received a vision from the goddess myself, Sister Ianth.  In it, I saw the fire of the Flame Stone quenched and an unnatural, brilliant white fire consuming the land around it.
[Ianth turns to you.] Then we must go to the Flame Stone at once! There is no time to waste.
We set off from Tethyr out of concern for you, Sister Ianth. We knew that the Flame Stone had been your destination, and thought that Sister Valeria's dream signified some evil that had befallen you.

[Maerdred shakes his head grimly.] But the danger has befallen the entire region. We rode here between two forces--one marches up the Sunset Trail from the south, and the other approaches from the east. The one from the east bore the flag of Zhentil Keep, and the other an unfamiliar banner that resembled that of the church of Lathander. They seem set to converge at the Flame Stone.
That sounds like Zhentarim and the Risen Sun!
Zhentil Keep?  Then the Banites sent reinforcements while the Cyricists were busy pursuing us.  The other force must belong to the cult that took over Darkhold.
What does that sound like to you, Ianth?
The Banite Zhentarim and the Cult of the Risen Sun, of course.
What could they want with the Flame Stone?
The Risen Sun?  I see we have much to discuss, but I fear there is little time.  But first, Ianth, tell us--What has kept you here for the past year?
[Ianth blushes deeply.] The rose that grows near the Flame Stone, the flower for which we Knights of the Ruby Rose make our pilgrimage--it never appeared for me.

If that is so, Ianth, then our present purpose and the purpose for which you originally came will meet tonight.  We will go to the Stone immediately, and you shall keep a vigil, even as we guard the place with our lives.
We will go ahead of you, on foot, as the way is woody and our horses unused to the terrain.  We will expect you this evening.  Do not tarry long!
My.  It seems we said our farewells at just the right time.  I hope, for all of our sakes, that whatever happens tonight is...for the best.
It will be, Hamfast.  It will be.
Hamfast, you need to alert everyone in town as soon as possible.  Whatever conflict arises at the Flame Stone could mean trouble for Drawn Swords.

I had better go to the Sword and Dragon at once and tell people the news, have them secure themselves.  Meanwhile, I'll tell Revelian to lock the place down.  I hope to see all of you again--some day!

I had better go to the Sword and Dragon at once and tell people the news, have them secure themselves.  Meanwhile, I'll tell Revelian to lock the place down.  I hope to see all of you again--some day!
Let us hear what more they have to say.
--Despite all the good we've done, we've worn out our welcome?
[Chuckling uneasily.] Something like that. You are good at disarming a man, .
--There is no need to say it, Hamfast.  We will leave as soon as possible.  We do not want to endanger you or Drawn Swords any further.
[Sighing in relief.] I'm glad we see eye to eye. I'd like nothing better than to have the lot of you here, but--well, you've said it yourself.
It's good that both the Cyricists and their mercenaries have been killed. Perhaps this will send a message to Zhentarim of all stripes that Drawn Swords ought not to be bothered.
[Ianth clenches her jaw resolutely as Hamfast speaks.]
Justice has been done...[Tell Hamfast about your encounter.]
[Shrug.] In a manner of speaking...[Tell Hamfast about your encounter.]
Good to see you again.  What can I do for you?
I would like to look at your arms and armor.
Well, I'm the town smith and the town leader.  My great-uncle was Saern Bairnson.  We Bairnsons were the ones who renovated Swordskeep and started building on the crag.
He died forty years ago, when I was just an apprentice smith.  A sad day for all of Drawn Swords.  I'm not ashamed to admit that no leader is likely ever to compare with him, including me.
What can you tell me about Drawn Swords?
Well, the town you see now has stood here for a little over a century.  This keep has been around for about twice as long, and belonged to an ill-tempered robber knight named Ludos.
No one can mention Drawn Swords without talking about the Sword and Dragon Inn.  Danmar's management of the place has made Drawn Swords a destination for travelers in the Backlands.
[Sleight of Hand] [Hamfast is not particularly attentive. You might be able to secure a small bag of what look like semiprecious stones from a nearby workbench.] Oh, I need nothing at the moment...
[Success] [You gingerly pick up the bag of stones and pocket it swiftly. Hamfast remains none the wiser.]

[Failure] Now, wait a minute!  I know that you are an adventurer, <FirstName>, but I can't have you traipsing out of here with those little jewels.  You'll have to find another blacksmith's shop to make an adventure out of.
Put them back where you found them, please.
I need nothing at the moment.  Farewell.
